Adam's 'evidence' is backed by survivor's bias i.e. of course if you ask people who fully transitioned to justify to you why they did it they will claim they always wanted to from a young age and never doubted or changed their mind, whether that is true or not. But that is not all children that express gender confusion, that's working backwards from the people you need to actually ask. 95%+ of children who experience gender confusion grow out of it, it really is simply a phase or they needed to sort something out. But now what if you force them into that decision under the guise of being tolerant? They pick up something pink once and you whisk them off to the doctor to immediately pump them full of chemicals to confirm your own ideology? This is already happening in sweden where therapists are pressuring girls with autism to transition and claim they're boys as the only explanation for their condition, and many of them are very dissatisfied and feel railroaded, because they were. You could say the reverse could happen, a parent stopping a child from being who they are, and hollywood makes a lot of hullabaloo about this scenario, but in real life, on the broad scale this is the less likely outcome and you are more likely to force a "normal" child to be strange to satisfy your own ego and they will grow up damaged or resentful.

replies.author: @sashaellis5053
replies.text: @imperfectious Irreversible actions aren't being performed on children, and it's not suggested that they should be. Trans children, are treated with hormone blockers, which simply delay puberty, until they're an adult, when they can begin hormone replacement therapy. If at any point they realize they're not trans, they can stop taking the puberty blockers, and their body will develop as it would otherwise. They do not, as the creator of this video repeatedly states, cause sterilization or  infertility. The treatment is shown to be greatly beneficial to mental health, as going through the puberty not associated with your gender identity is often a very traumatic experience, and makes transitioning later in life a far more arduous process

author: @lenonkitchens7727
text:
As the father of a 6 and a half year old, and a teacher of several 6 to 10 year olds in certain settings, and the husband of a woman who teaches k-9th grade, let me assure you that a 6-10 year old is absolutely incapable of making a decision like this about their health.

You can even trust them to brush their teeth properly, or take their vitamins without being told.  What makes *anyone* think they are capable of understand the ramifications of hormone therapy, and choosing whether or not to take it?

Not that the parents are any more capable.  The kids I know change literally anything and everything about themselves and the way they think from day to day.  You cannot have any objective knowledge about their gender.  The only rational course of action is to let them make their own decision one they are an adult.  Anything else is child abuse.

I had gender dysphoria as a kid, I am a "feminine" male.  I had almost exclusively female friends, and I fantasize about life as a woman, however I am "Cis-Accepting" I believe I subscribed to gender stereotypes as kid and thought I would be more normal if I was a woman.  I fear if I was a kid today...  Parents using gender stereotypes to gender their kids, or let kids gender themselves...  When we should be sending the message that it is OK to be a feminine male.  We should break down gender stereotypes instead of this.

My dysphoria faded significantly post puberty, and I came to see my feminine side a huge advantage, now I am proud that I can see with the mind of a woman.

I am feminine in that I am emotive, empathetic, and more interested in people than things.  I enjoy time with children, and I am pain and adrenaline adverse.

My behavior is feminine, but I would be more than valuable if the call to defend my property came.

However, if you think you need war to thrive, you should read about the life of Mahatma Gandhi, and the power of pacifist protest.

You and the extreme left can both learn something from United peaceful demonstration.

Who is coming for us?

China? Unlikely, they depend on us for food, %40 of their food supply is imported from the north america.  We live in global co-dependence with eachother, if war breaks out all will suffer, especially those living in urban environments, food and fuel shortages will occur almost immediately. 

These are troubling times indeed for the future of civilization.

replies.author: @kevinbarbour2771
replies.text:
Chess already has something like this.  Men compete in Open events that anyone can join and in Invitational events that anyone can qualify for.  Women can compete in any open and can qualify for invitational but can also compete in separate women's only events.  The titles like Master, National Master, International Master, and Grand Master are available to any who complete the specified requirements but can also attain women's only titles like Women's Master, Women's International Master, Women's Grand Master, that have lower requirements.  Anyone who plays well enough can qualify for the Candidates cycle and challenge for the World Championship while there is also a separate Women's World Championship just for the ladies.

However, no woman has ever qualified for the World Championship (though Judit Polgar did qualify for the Candidates cycle once) nor to my knowledge has one ever defeated a reigning World Champion (though Judit had a controversial touch move game against Garry Kasparov once) .  Only one woman, Judit Polgar, has ever broken into the world's top ten players.  Currently, there is only one woman in the world's top 100 players.  Due to these facts they still say Chess is sexist.  Trans people could play in the men's events like anyone but idk about women's events.

author: @JT-iw2cw
text: I'm bothered by this "I wish to god I had the choice when I was young" argument. One part is the inability to choose one's own genetics. Everybody feels this to some extent.  People often say, "I wish I had a bigger D", "I wish I had bigger boobs", smaller nose etc. These are all common thoughts that everybody has, but the fact is, we can't change that stuff genetically. Some might surgically alter themselves later on in life and wish they could have experienced our teen years with what they view as a more picturesque body. Rather than alter these things in the first place, or spend our time wishing things were different, we should learn to accept our perceived faults . These faults are only viewed from our own perception and these perceived deficiencies are overblown and often false. In most cases if you could relive your life over again with "better" genes, parts or hormonal balance, you would find that you'd still be the awkward, confused and ridiculous person you are now, but with  different things you dislike about yourself. The point is, you can't escape yourself. Wherever you go, there you are.

How about not pushing kids into any big decisions until they're not kids anymore.
